ratings.comment: I think he truly is a great professor that explains things clearly and cares about his students. Tests seemed easier than the practice exams.

Lectures were taken word for word from the textbook. 15-question multiple choice exams being the majority of the grade made the class extremely stressful. He is a nice person but far from the best physics professor out there (although I don't know if 202 could ever be good necessarily).

Difficult to understand, due to his thick accent and the fact that he spoke quietly. Did a lot of writing on the board, which was difficult to read from most places in the large lecture hall. Tests were difficult.

Multiple choice in physics makes me want to throw up. Final exam for fall 2017 semester was extremely difficult, and not at all similar to the easy practice exams given. 1/2 the problems required concept weaving at an instructor level. Makes you wonder whether they deliberately try to make the most difficult exam possible just as a pissing contest

Gary is better but he's still good. He teaches the first midterm material and then a little bit before the final exam. Lectures are boring but content is interesting and applicable. Homework is doable and exams are okay.  Study old exams.

It's a pretty tough class, so you definitely have to pay attention and do the work to succeed. Willing to stay after class and answer questions which is very helpful. Your success in this class is going to depend a lot on how good your TA is.

He's a very straightforward teacher. It's not an easy class, but if you keep up, you should be fine. He gives out a practice test before each exam that is almost the same as the actual exam. (I took this class in the summer, so it was probably easier than during the regular semester.)
He talks really fast, but his lectures are really informative!

He is unclear and just reads off of the power point. He reviews the material from the previous lecture, but using the exact same power point slides and wording, so it's not in more depth or explained better, just more repetitive. Lecture is basically useless in this course.

Puts little to no effort into teaching the class. It's like there's an invisible man standing up there prodding him with a stick forcing him to lecture. He just stands there and reads off the slides. Homework and tests cover material we were never taught in lecture. Read the textbook during lecture and attend discussions to pass.

This guy was no help when it came to learning physics. The only thing that sort of helped was his lecture slides because it gave you the general equations. I stopped going to lecture 2 weeks in and ended up with a B.

This class is not easy. Requires quite a bit of work, and Stan doesn't make it any easier. Lectures weren't very helpful, but at least he has a fun, Despicable Me-esque Russian accent. Hope you get a TA that can explain things a little better.

Class sucks. His teaching style is pretty unclear and he tends to ramble on again and again about the same things while giving you no insight into what the tests will be on. Tests are 20 multiple choice questions, no partial credit. NONE. This is not how a physics class should be run, but it's not his fault. Likely is the standard for this class.

Lecture was useless.  Read directly off powerpoint slides and never actually worked a problem or even discussed how to apply the material to problems.  Exams not at all based on lecture material, making them tremendously difficult to prepare for.  Massively disappointing for someone very interested in physics.

I visited him in his office to talk about confusions I had regarding my scantrons, and he was very approachable and happy to help. Also would have helped me with learning the material, but it was so far over my head I didn't know where to start. Probably gets a lower rating than he deserves simply because he teaches a difficult class jointly with a less approachable prof.

Poor Stanislav--he really wants to help his students, but his lectures can be nearly incomprehensible. The material isn't bad, but it can be difficult to wrap your head around what he's trying to say. I hear he can be helpful outside of class. I do credit him with being in tune with his lecture and knowing when students don't get it.
